title: Price of beer to SOAR as government prepare crippling new pub tax
text:
GETTY CAN YOU BELIEVE IT: The price could go up by 30p 
Pub favourites Wetherspoons could be among the many pubs in the firing line for the increase. 
As many as 17,160 of pubs in England and Wales could be affected by the price change in April, according to rents and rates specialists CVS. 
The price could go up by 30p – which could see pub-goers spend a staggering £70.17million more than in 2016/2017. 
Wetherspoons founder and chairman Tim Martin is urging for "tax equality" as his chain's rates face a rise of £7million – at about £8,000 per pub. 
GETTY FAVES: Wetherspoons could be among the many pubs in the firing line for increase “Our rates will rise by about £7 million per annum or around £8,000 per pub per annum” Tim Martin 
He told MailOnline: "Our rates will rise by about £7 million per annum or around £8,000 per pub per annum. 
"That is about 16%. This will take rates per pint in a pub up to around 18p from the current 16p. 
"Supermarkets, in contrast, pay only about 2p per pint in business rates – and there will be almost no increase for them in April. 
"This compounds the real unfairness – supermarkets pay no VAT on food sales and pubs pay 20 per cent, enabling supermarkets to subsidise alcoholic drink prices." GETTY KNOCK ON: 17,160 of pubs in England and Wales could be affected 
But CAMRA's National Vice Chairman Jackie Parker has said it is consumers who are going to be hit in the pocket. 
And she claimed it is the wellbeing of the British people that could be at stake. 
Ms Parker said: "Ultimately, it will be the consumers who pay the price as publicans are forced to put up prices. 
"Enjoying a pint in a pub has a hugely beneficial impact on a person's wellbeing."

Amid fears pubs will be forced to close down, The Campaign for Real Ale is urging a £5,000 reduction rate for owners. 
A government spokesman told MailOnline: “From April a third of all businesses will be taken out of business rates altogether and nearly a million businesses will see their bills cut thanks to the biggest ever cut in rates – worth £6.7 billion. 
“We know that the Great British pub is a national asset, providing thousands of jobs and boosting the economy by £21 billion a year, and have worked with the five major trade bodies to agree a method of valuing pubs.” Related articles
